body.p: NullSoft Scriptable Install System (NSIS) is the software installation framework used. It is a script-driven Windows installation system. The following links may be accessed for details and download:
The installation process must clear the associated test script or STS prepared.

ul.li: Ensure the BUSMASTER Installer.nsi script is residing under Installation Setup and the application artifacts residing under the Sources folder under same directory.

The setup is depicted in the diagram below which shows how the installer build generation process is initiated by User and how the script accesses the artifacts from various locations under Sources folder. Prior to building the script, the artifacts needs to be generated by building the BUSMASTER application in Visual studio environment (VC++).

In the script file, register the inproc, local and remote servers which are being part of the installation folder using the script command examples below: ExecWait 'BusEmulation.exe /regserver' ExecWait '"$SYSDIR\regsvr32.exe" /s "Sample.dll"

body.p: Make sure the path of the .exe or .dll file is set as outpath before executing the above commands. The following command does that: SetOutPath $INSTDIR

Consider an example script for registration as shown below:SetOutPath $INSTDIR ExecWait 'BusEmulation.exe /regserver'
SetOutPath $INSTDIR/MinGW ExecWait '"$SYSDIR\regsvr32.exe" /s "Sample.dll"

In the above example, BusEmulation.exe lies within the target directory so the outpath is set to the same. The Sample.dll exists under the MinGW folder in target directory, so the outpath is set accordingly to $INSTDIR/MinGW.
The registrations should take place only after the binaries get copied to the target folders. Also the un-registrations should take place before uninstalling the binaries from the system.

section.title: Windows 7 specific settings in install script:
section.p: The BUSMASTER.exe and BUSEmulation.exe needs to run with "WIN98 compatibility" setting to run smoothly under windows 7 OS.
In order to set the compatibility mode, the following registry keys have been added under the registry if the installed environment is windows 7.

The operating system details are read using the following script: ReadRegStr $1 HKLM "SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion" CurrentVersion ; Current version value of 6.1 denotes Windows 7 OS StrCmp $1 "6.1" 0 lbl ; StrCmp str1 str2 jump_if_equal [jump_if_not_equal]
The registry entries should actually be added under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE but windows 7 prevents 32-bit Null soft installer exe from writing to HKLM location.
